interactivity: its hinged lid could be opened
hapticFeedback: Users press and lift the hinged lid: they will feel a firm, lightly-damped torque at the hinge that gives resistance as they open, followed by a subtle “click” or stop when fully deployed. The lid’s edge and latch area should convey the coarse grain of weathered wood under the fingertips—slight ridges and grooves along the planks—as well as the smooth, cool inlay of any metal bands. Contact will occur primarily on the front lip of the lid and the latch. A good physical proxy is a small wooden box with an actual hinge: the user must push against wood grain friction and feel the metal hinge’s resistance and endpoint click.

Grasping and manipulating the key, users will feel a continuous smooth loop around their finger: the ring shank should feel like a hollow or solid metal loop, with a polished surface and rounded edges. The slender cylindrical shaft and flat bit will present crisp, bevelled corners under thumb and forefinger. Contact is concentrated on the ring and the shaft. A good proxy is any real house key or similarly sized smooth metal fob: it conveys the ring-shape holding part and slim shank.

When the user rests their grip on the frame, they feel a hard, angular plastic or metal body under the palm. The index finger on the trigger experiences an initial light preload followed by a distinct break and a crisp tactile “snap” as the trigger is pulled. Contact parts are the grip’s contours and the trigger itself. A suitable proxy is a toy or airsoft pistol frame with a working trigger: it provides the same pull force curve and clear mechanical break.

description: a frisbee that players can throw
outline: holding part feels like a thin plate
hapticFeedback: Holding the disc by its outer rim, users sense a thin, stiff plate profile about 2–3 mm thick. The rim edge feels slightly rounded but rigid, and the overall mass is very light—users detect minimal inertia and can flick it easily. Contact is around the circumference between thumb and fingers. A standard plastic flying disc serves as an ideal proxy, matching the thin-plate outline and low weight.

description: a steering wheel in a car
hapticFeedback: Users wrap both hands around a circular rim (about 40 cm diameter) and feel a smooth, slightly grippy surface under their palms and fingertips. As they rotate, there is a low-torque, gently damped resistance—no hard stops, but subtle feedback from internal friction. Contact is continuous along the top half of the rim. A small automotive steering wheel or bicycle handlebar section bent into a circle offers a good proxy, providing the same rounded profile and rotational feel.

When squeezed, the tomato yields under pressure: users feel an initial soft skin tension, then a gradual giving as the sides bulge outward, with a quick spring-back when released. There is no hard surface—only a smooth, uniform compliance. Contact occurs across the palm or fingertip pads. A soft stress-ball or squishy toy with a smooth outer membrane is an excellent proxy, matching the same softness and elastic deformation.

inertia: relatively heavy with the center of mass concentrated at one end
hapticFeedback: Grasping the round handle (approximately 2.5 cm diameter), users sense a firm cylindrical shaft leading to a blocky, heavy head. The weight feels biased toward the head, producing a clear forward moment when swung. There is low handle compliance and a solid endpoint when the head contacts a surface. Primary contact is on the handle just below the head. A short metal-headed hammer or mallet with a straight wooden or metal shaft closely replicates this weight distribution and handle outline.
